subject: Re: [junit] How to Test Private Methods Inside a Class
msgSnippet: ... While that is true I don t feel constrained having only one. I see very limited additional value of a method like that. But hey, that is just me, I would
messageBody:
> > I kind of like the way you do it in Java, create a BufferedReader and
> > use readLine(). I think the Stream abstraction is really elegant and
> > much prefer to work with it than directly with files.
>
> No reason we can't have both.

While that is true I don't feel constrained having only one.
I see very limited additional value of a method like that. But hey,
that is just me, I would certainly not suffer if it was there unless I
was in a project where someone used it in a place where
Streams/Readers would be a better choice, which in my book is the
majority of situations.

>
> Also, why do I have to write that loop every time? How often have you
> wanted to read only one line from that BufferedReader? Where the hell is
> BufferedReader.readLines() that returns an array or List of lines?!

I have never (as far as I remember) wanted to read just one line from
the reader but I typically process them one at the time so I might
aswell do that /while/ reading from the stream rather than read all
lines from the stream into memory and /then/ loop through the strings
to process them one at the time.

Of course sometimes I don't care about lines at all...

> > Of course, that is just one mans opinion that may change after working
> > with Ruby,
>
>
> That's always possible.
Indeed

Cheers!
/Joakim Ohlrogge
